fields.headline: Critics' choice
fields.bodyText: The book Rubies in the Snow by Kate Hubbard Short Books. Price £5.99. Age 11+ yrs In June 1911 (so this story goes), Anastasia Romanov, youngest daughter of Tsar Nicholas II, is given a diary for her 10th birthday; a diary in which she records the daily events of her life. Hers is not an ordinary life, but her preoccupations are those of pre-teenagers everywhere - sibling rivalry, clothes, schoolwork. Through the glass of Anastasia's naive optimism we see the onset of war in Russia and the scurrilous rumours surrounding the enigmatic figure of "our friend" Rasputin. Gradually and guardedly, Anastasia is exposed to the news of unrest sweeping Russia, though the gloss of filial devotion doesn't permit much insight into the people's disaffection with their tsar. For much of the diary, the narrative voice remains that of the 10-year-old girl, cheerfully good-humoured even when her family is eventually imprisoned in its palace. Only when her family is sent to Siberia does the tone change and a degree of greater understanding prevail, as matters rush headlong to their abrupt and brutal conclusion. A brief afterword outlines events on the morning of July 17 1918; readers engrossed by Anastasia's fascinating story will be left eager to find out more. The web Science: solar system and beyond www.bnsc.gov.uk Suitable for: KS3 teachers & pupils Select the learning zone from the menu. The space explorers section has plenty of information on the planets and much about the history of manned exploration. There are also worksheets covering such issues as the shape of the moon, the seasons and the atmosphere. www.nationalgeographic.org/solarsystem Suitable for: KS3 teachers & pupils A spectacular solar system flypast is available, consisting of a visit to the sun, followed by each of the planets (including Pluto) in turn. Comets, asteroids and meteors are covered, too. www.space.com Suitable for: KS3/4 teachers & pupils This is packed with news about space activities and discoveries, terrific photography, games and interesting facts. There are also some interesting links, including one to Seti for the latest news on the search for extraterrestrial intelligence. www.spacedout-uk.com Suitable for: KS2/3/4 teachers & pupils A virtual tour of the solar system with a difference can be found here. When the names of the objects are selected, photographs of interesting sculptures at schools and other places of interest are presented. There are also "wacky facts" about the planets that cover not only the usual facts but also details of how it got its name, discovery information and other interesting facts and speculation. A resources section offers worksheets, lesson ideas, word searches and many other materials aimed at particular age groups. A gallery of pictures submitted by schools, colleges and amateur astronomers is also available, and a quiz should be added soon. Details are also provided of a project to build the world's largest scale model of the solar system at Jodrell Bank. www.bbc.co.uk/skyatnight Suitable for: KS3/4 teachers & pupils Running since 1957, this programme has a long history of explaining space to the people of Britain. The website contains lots of useful material, including a special section devoted to the solar system.
